candidates.title: Fix msrv
candidates.body:
As I noted in https://github.com/mthom/scryer-prolog/discussions/2784#discussioncomment-14137557
when I made #3009 I forgot that we wanted to keep the MSRV at 1.85 for compatibility with debian trixi.

This fixes that mistake by detecting the current rust version and falling back to a different implementation on rust < 1.87.0.

candidates.title: library(numerics), special funs from crate puruspe
candidates.body: This PR contains a 'numerics' library with special math functions from the `puruspe` crate, which I've needed for sampling from probability distributions the [DEDUCTION project](https://codeberg.org/dcnorris/DEDUCTION). I've used `quads` quite extensively here, especially for testing.

candidates.title: adds predicates for spawning new processes without a shell
candidates.body:
API identified as missing in https://github.com/Seeker04/plwm/discussions/102#discussioncomment-13768976

Attempts to be mostly compatible with [swi-prolog](https://www.swi-prolog.org/pldoc/doc_for?object=process_create/3).

## Not Planed

- Options
  - stdio(pipe(Stream, StreamOptions))
  - stdio(stream(Stream))
  - detached(Bool)
  - window(Bool)
  - priority(Prioriy)
- Windows
  - rust args quoting behavior likely differs from swi-prolog

## Todo

- [x] stdio(pipe(Stream)) binding the Stream var to the created stream doesn't appear to work (help wanted)
- [x] process(Pid) binding the spawned processes pid doesn't appear to work  (help wanted)
- [x] rename pid to process to match [swi-prolog](https://www.swi-prolog.org/pldoc/doc_for?object=process_create/3)
- [x] Proper errors, see https://github.com/mthom/scryer-prolog/pull/3009#issuecomment-3094428068
- [x] How/Where to store the Child object returned by Command::spawn? We need it to wait/kill the child (suggestions welcome)
  - [x] process_release/1, process_wait/2, process_wait/3
  - [x] process_kill/1
- [x] add tests
- [x] add documentation

candidates.title: rebis-dev: add opt-in concurrency for OffsetTableImpl
candidates.body:
The global tables of `offset_table.rs` are removed in favour of a sum type, owned by `Arena`, that can be toggled between `Serial` and `Concurrent` variants. Offset table lookups must now be performed explicitly instead of implicitly, which the `read_heap_cell!` macro no longer does. The machine can migrate the table data from `Serial` to `Concurrent` when spawning a new thread from the parent machine thread for the first time and back from `Concurrent` to `Serial` again once all child machine threads have been joined / offset table access can safely happen without synchronization once more. This addresses the performance issue raised in #2908 in single-threaded Scryer.

I've created this PR instead of merging the commit directly to `rebis-dev` because I'm not sure I've implemented it quite right. Previously the offset table had type `Arcu<RawBlock<OffsetTableImpl<T>>, GlobalEpochCounter>` instead of `Arc<RawBlock<T>, GlobalEpochCounter>`, for instance. I don't know why `OffsetTableImpl<T>` appeared recursively in that type but I'm sure there was a reason.

I'd appreciate feedback from @Skgland particularly, as the author of the `arcu` crate, and anyone else who cares to weigh in on this or any other potential problems in this PR. Thanks.

candidates.title: Remove obsolete compatibility for Rust<1.80
candidates.body: This code was introduced in #2457 to use `LazyLock`, introduced in Rust 1.80. The targeted Rust version was 1.77 in Cargo.toml. Now that Cargo.toml lists the minimum version as 1.85, this compilation flag is no longer necessary.

candidates.title: Update dependencies and fix breaking changes in libffi-sys and arcu
candidates.body: Updates dependencies, and also addresses #2749 and #2952 making it actually possible to use Scryer master (and rebis-dev if it eventually gets this through rebase/cherry-pick/merge) as a dependency without having to jump through a thousand hoops.

candidates.title: Bump MSRV and update flake.lock
candidates.body:
Let's get this over with.

This bumps the Minimum Supported Rust Version from 1.77 to 1.85, the Rust version officially supported in Debian Trixie. It also bumps flake.lock because Rust there was pinned to a version older than that. This gives us access to strict provenance (#2019), Rust 2024 edition if we want, and also eliminates (at least temporarily) the whole annoyance of making sure the build and all dependencies work with a version of Rust that is almost a year old at this point.

This also fixes CI on master, which currently fails just because of 1.77.

candidates.title: Update `libffi` and `libffi-sys` dependencies to fix aarch64 macOS build
candidates.body: Pulls in latest `libffi` and `libffi-sys` dependencies to fix a compilation error on aarch64 macOS builds.

candidates.title: Update and clean up dependencies.
candidates.body: Just updated Cargo.lock and made a few major upgrades too. Ended up removing 5 advisories from the output of `cargo audit` and finding some unused dependencies. See the commit messages for details.

candidates.title: Wasm rework
candidates.body:
This reworks the Wasm API to match the Rust API and therefore be much more flexible (query iterators allowing continuous feedback and infinite leaf answers, actual term data representation instead of just strings, etc...). This was some of the trickiest Rust code I've ever wrote (self-referential structs, single threaded channels, etc...), but I managed to do all of it without using unsafe. If anyone has suggestions on how to do it better please tell me. If anyone has suggestions on how to make the interface more idiomatic for Javascript I would also like to hear it!

This is still very rough and needs polish (and documentation, which I intentionally deferred), but already works really well as is.

Non-goals for this PR:

- Have a way to capture stdout like the removed `eval_code`, and some way to interface with stdin. This is needed for eventually running the CLI toplevel in Scryer Playground. Doing this properly depends on #2799, and I will do that in another PR. Just having access to queries is already powerful enough for the vast majority of use cases.
- Settle on a serialization. This would definitely have been easier to do if we had decided on a serialization (#2707), but it doesn't depend on it.
- WASI or pure Wasm. These are also applications of Wasm I think we should tackle eventually, but this PR is concerned specifically with embedding Scryer Prolog in Javascript (the browser and things like NodeJS). WASI doesn't need any special treatment interface-wise, and pure Wasm will come for free with #2464.

candidates.title: Fix UB when interacting with Stream::Null(_)
add ffi tests & fix ffi
candidates.body:
Ovehauls the ffi implementation.

- adds various tests
  - https://github.com/mthom/scryer-prolog/pull/2777#discussion_r1922859879
  - https://github.com/mthom/scryer-prolog/pull/2777#discussion_r1922793229
  - and many more
- replace a lot of low level libffi usage with higher level api usage 
- adds type aliases so that rust type names for integer types can be used (float types already used f32/f64)
- add support for cstr in return types and when unpacking structs
- properly throw errors instead of crashing in several invalid egde cases
- properly handle some edge cases (e.g. integers that can't fit in a fixnum)
